newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Western Australia faces power cuts from Thursday.
newsitem.headline: Western Australia faces power cuts from Thursday.

text.p: Western Australia is likely to have power cuts from Thursday morning because of industrial action over new industrial relations legislation, state-owned electricity generator Western Power said on Wednesday.

A Western Power spokesman said coal handlers at Muja power station in Collie in the state's southwest, who stopped work for 48 hours on Tuesday over the legislation, offered to return to work on a limited basis on Wednesday but the offer was rejected.
"They wanted to go back to work to make sufficient coal to ensure enough power for domestic users," the spokesman said.
"We wanted a full return to work as per the commitment given to Western Power by unions yesterday," he said.
"So the power restrictions stay on and there is the possibility of power cuts starting tomorrow morning," he said.
A 24-hour "day of action" to protest against proposed changes to state industrial relations laws produced widespread but patchy disruption of the state's economy on Tuesday.

The state's trade union movement believes the new legislation is anti-union. As well as providing for pre-strike secret ballots, the legislation limits union access to work sites and non-union employee records and disallows political donations by unions without majority membership support.
Australian trades union leaders said on Wednesday they might ask colleagues in Asia to impose trade bans to support industrial action in Western Australia over the new labour laws.
